title: Drake Ties JAY-Z & Taylor Swift for Most No. 1s Among Soloists on Billboard 200
description: Overall, only The Beatles have more No. 1s on the Billboard 200 albums chart.
author: Keith Caulfield
excerpt: Drake ties JAY-Z and Taylor Swift for the most No. 1 albums among soloists in the history of the Billboard 200 chart.
text: Overall, only The Beatles have more No. 1s on the Billboard 200 albums chart. Drake Courtesy OVO Sound As PARTYNEXTDOOR and Drake’s first collaborative album, $ome $exy $ongs 4 U, debuts atop the Billboard 200 chart (dated March 1), it marks PARTYNEXTDOOR’s first leader, and the 14th chart-topper for Drake. In turn, Drake now ties JAY-Z and Taylor Swift for the most No. 1s among soloists in the nearly-69-year history of the chart. Overall, only The Beatles, with 19 No. 1s, have more. Drake captured his first leader in 2010 with Thank Me Later. The Billboard 200 chart ranks the most popular albums of the week in the U.S. based on multi-metric consumption as measured in equivalent album units, compiled by Luminate. Units comprise album sales, track equivalent albums (TEA) and streaming equivalent albums (SEA). Each unit equals one album sale, or 10 individual tracks sold from an album, or 3,750 ad-supported or 1,250 paid/subscription on-demand official audio and video streams generated by songs from an album. The new March 1, 2025-dated chart will be posted in full on Billboard‘s website on Feb. 25. For all chart news, follow @billboard and @billboardcharts on both X, formerly known as Twitter, and Instagram. A collaborative project from PARTYNEXTDOOR and Drake had been teased for months, but was only officially announced on Feb. 3, in advance of its release on Feb. 14. $ome $exy $ongs 4 U is the third collab project from Drake to reach No. 1 on the Billboard 200, following pairings with 21 Savage (Her Loss in 2022) and Future (What a Time to Be Alive in 2015). Here’s a look at every act with 10 or more No. 1 albums on the Billboard 200, as well as all 14 of Drake’s leaders. Every Act With at Least 10 No. 1s on the Billboard 200: 19, The Beatles 14, Drake 14, JAY-Z 14, Taylor Swift 11, Eminem 11, Future 11, Bruce Springsteen 11, Barbra Streisand 11, Ye (formerly Kanye West) 10, Elvis Presley (Since the Billboard 200 began publishing on a regular, weekly basis in March 1956) Drake’s 14 No. 1s on the Billboard 200: Title; Peak Date; Weeks at No. 1 Thank Me Later; July 3, 2010; one Take Care; Dec. 3, 2011; one Nothing Was the Same; Oct. 12, 2013; one If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late; Feb. 28, 2015; one What a Time To Be Alive (with Future); Oct. 10, 2015; one Views; May 21, 2016; 13 More Life; April 8, 2017; three Scorpion; July 14, 2018; five Care Package; Aug. 17, 2019; one Certified Lover Boy; Sept. 18, 2021; five Honestly, Nevermind; July 2, 2022;  one Her Loss (with 21 Savage); Nov. 19, 2022; one For All the Dogs; Oct. 21, 2023; two $ome $exy $ongs 4 U (with PARTYNEXTDOOR); March 1, 2025; one to date Get weekly rundowns straight to your inbox Sign Up
html:
Overall, only The Beatles have more No. 1s on the Billboard 200 albums chart.

As PARTYNEXTDOOR and Drake’s first collaborative album, $ome $exy $ongs 4 U, debuts atop the Billboard 200 chart (dated March 1), it marks PARTYNEXTDOOR’s first leader, and the 14th chart-topper for Drake.

In turn, Drake now ties JAY-Z and Taylor Swift for the most No. 1s among soloists in the nearly-69-year history of the chart. Overall, only The Beatles, with 19 No. 1s, have more. Drake captured his first leader in 2010 with Thank Me Later.

The Billboard 200 chart ranks the most popular albums of the week in the U.S. based on multi-metric consumption as measured in equivalent album units, compiled by Luminate. Units comprise album sales, track equivalent albums (TEA) and streaming equivalent albums (SEA). Each unit equals one album sale, or 10 individual tracks sold from an album, or 3,750 ad-supported or 1,250 paid/subscription on-demand official audio and video streams generated by songs from an album. The new March 1, 2025-dated chart will be posted in full on Billboard‘s website on Feb. 25. For all chart news, follow @billboard and @billboardcharts on both X, formerly known as Twitter, and Instagram.

A collaborative project from PARTYNEXTDOOR and Drake had been teased for months, but was only officially announced on Feb. 3, in advance of its release on Feb. 14. $ome $exy $ongs 4 U is the third collab project from Drake to reach No. 1 on the Billboard 200, following pairings with 21 Savage (Her Loss in 2022) and Future (What a Time to Be Alive in 2015).

Here’s a look at every act with 10 or more No. 1 albums on the Billboard 200, as well as all 14 of Drake’s leaders.

  • Every Act With at Least 10 No. 1s on the Billboard 200:

    • 19, The Beatles
    • 14, Drake
    • 14, JAY-Z
    • 14, Taylor Swift
    • 11, Eminem
    • 11, Future
    • 11, Bruce Springsteen
    • 11, Barbra Streisand
    • 11, Ye (formerly Kanye West)
    • 10, Elvis Presley

    (Since the Billboard 200 began publishing on a regular, weekly basis in March 1956)

  • Drake’s 14 No. 1s on the Billboard 200:

    Title; Peak Date; Weeks at No. 1

    • Thank Me Later; July 3, 2010; one
    • Take Care; Dec. 3, 2011; one
    • Nothing Was the Same; Oct. 12, 2013; one
    • If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late; Feb. 28, 2015; one
    • What a Time To Be Alive (with Future); Oct. 10, 2015; one
    • Views; May 21, 2016; 13
    • More Life; April 8, 2017; three
    • Scorpion; July 14, 2018; five
    • Care Package; Aug. 17, 2019; one
    • Certified Lover Boy; Sept. 18, 2021; five
    • Honestly, Nevermind; July 2, 2022;  one
    • Her Loss (with 21 Savage); Nov. 19, 2022; one
    • For All the Dogs; Oct. 21, 2023; two
    • $ome $exy $ongs 4 U (with PARTYNEXTDOOR); March 1, 2025; one to date
